Description: Alpinia Galanga, commonly known as Rasna, is a perennial herb belonging to the ginger family (Zingiberaceae). It is native to Southeast Asia and is known for its aromatic rhizomes. Rasna is used in traditional medicine and culinary practices for its medicinal properties and flavor.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Rasna is found in tropical regions of Southeast Asia, including countries like India, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Thailand. It typically grows in moist, shaded areas.
Growing_Requirements: Rasna thrives in well-drained soil and prefers partial shade to full shade. It requires a warm and humid climate for optimal growth.
Uses_and_Benefits: Rasna has been traditionally used for its anti-inflammatory, digestive, and analgesic properties. It is also used as a spice in cooking, especially in Southeast Asian cuisines.
Conservation_Status: The conservation status of Alpinia Galanga may vary depending on the specific geographical regions where it is found. Local conservation authorities or botanical surveys can provide more information.

Description: Amaranths Viridis, commonly known as Arive-Dantu, is an annual herbaceous plant belonging to the Amaranthaceae family. It is known for its edible leaves and is cultivated as a leafy vegetable in many parts of the world.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Arive-Dantu is found in various regions globally, including Asia, Africa, and the Americas. It thrives in warm climates and can grow in a wide range of soil conditions.
Growing_Requirements: Arive-Dantu grows well in fertile, well-drained soil with sufficient moisture. It prefers full sun but can tolerate partial shade.
Uses_and_Benefits: The leaves of Arive-Dantu are rich in nutrients and are consumed as a nutritious vegetable. They are often used in salads, stir-fries, and soups.
Conservation_Status: Amaranths Viridis is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Artocarpus Heterophyllus, commonly known as Jackfruit, is a tropical tree belonging to the Moraceae family. It is known for its large fruit, which is the largest tree-borne fruit in the world. Jackfruit is widely cultivated for its edible and versatile flesh.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Jackfruit is native to the Indian subcontinent and is now cultivated in various tropical regions worldwide. It grows well in tropical lowland areas with a humid climate.
Growing_Requirements: Jackfruit trees prefer a warm and tropical climate. They require well-drained soil and perform best in areas with abundant sunlight.
Uses_and_Benefits: The ripe and unripe fruits of Jackfruit are used in culinary applications. The ripe fruit has a sweet flavor and is consumed fresh or used in desserts, while the unripe fruit is often used as a meat substitute in vegan and vegetarian dishes. Management of Type II diabetes mellitus.
Conservation_Status: Artocarpus Heterophyllus is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Basella Alba, commonly known as Basale or Malabar Spinach, is a leafy green vine belonging to the Basellaceae family. It is native to tropical regions of Asia and is cultivated for its edible leaves.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Basale is found in various tropical regions, including India, Sri Lanka, and Southeast Asia. It thrives in warm and humid climates and is often grown as a backyard vegetable.
Growing_Requirements: Basale prefers fertile, well-drained soil and requires ample sunlight. It can tolerate a range of temperatures but thrives in warm conditions.
Uses_and_Benefits: The leaves of Basale are rich in nutrients and are consumed as a leafy vegetable. They are often used in salads, stir-fries, and traditional dishes in Asian cuisines.
Conservation_Status: Basella Alba is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Brassica Juncea, commonly known as Indian Mustard or Brown Mustard, is a leafy green and oilseed crop belonging to the Brassicaceae family. It is widely cultivated for its edible leaves and oil-rich seeds.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Indian Mustard is believed to have originated in the Himalayan region of India and is now cultivated in many countries worldwide. It grows well in temperate climates.
Growing_Requirements: Indian Mustard prefers well-drained soil and requires cool temperatures for optimal growth. It can tolerate frost and is often grown as a winter crop.
Uses_and_Benefits: The leaves of Indian Mustard are used as a leafy vegetable, particularly in Indian cuisine. The seeds are crushed to produce mustard oil, which is used in cooking and as a condiment.
Conservation_Status: Brassica Juncea is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Carissa Carandas, commonly known as Karanda or Bengal Currant, is a small, evergreen shrub belonging to the Apocynaceae family. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and is cultivated for its edible berries.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Karanda is found in various parts of India, as well as in neighboring countries like Bangladesh, Pakistan, and Nepal. It grows in diverse habitats, including forests, scrublands, and cultivated areas.
Growing_Requirements: Karanda thrives in well-drained soil and can tolerate a wide range of temperatures. It prefers full sun to partial shade.
Uses_and_Benefits: The berries of Karanda are edible and have a sour taste. They are used in various culinary preparations, such as chutneys, jams, and beverages. The plant also has traditional medicinal uses.
Conservation_Status: Carissa Carandas is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Citrus Limon, commonly known as Lemon, is a small evergreen tree belonging to the Rutaceae family. It is native to Asia and is widely cultivated for its acidic and aromatic fruits.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Lemons are cultivated in many countries with suitable climates, including regions like India, Mexico, and the Mediterranean. They require a subtropical climate to thrive.
Growing_Requirements: Lemon trees prefer well-drained, slightly acidic soil and require a sunny location. They are sensitive to frost and grow best in regions with mild winters.
Uses_and_Benefits: Lemons are known for their high vitamin C content and their tangy flavor. They are used in cooking, beverages, and as a flavoring agent. Lemon juice also has various culinary and medicinal applications.
Conservation_Status: Citrus Limon is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Ficus Auriculata, commonly known as Roxburgh fig or Elephant ear fig, is a large evergreen tree belonging to the Moraceae family. It is native to South and Southeast Asia and is known for its broad, ear-shaped leaves and aerial roots.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Roxburgh fig trees can be found in various parts of South and Southeast Asia, including India, Sri Lanka, Thailand, and Malaysia. They typically grow in forests and are often seen near water bodies.
Growing_Requirements: Roxburgh figs prefer well-drained soil and a tropical or subtropical climate. They thrive in areas with abundant sunlight and high humidity.
Uses_and_Benefits: The fruit of Ficus Auriculata is edible and has a sweet and juicy taste. It is consumed fresh or used in traditional dishes in some regions. The tree also has cultural and religious significance in certain communities.
Conservation_Status: Ficus Auriculata is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Ficus Religiosa, commonly known as Peepal Tree or Bodhi Tree, is a large deciduous tree belonging to the Moraceae family. It is considered sacred in several religions and is known for its heart-shaped leaves.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Peepal trees are native to the Indian subcontinent and can be found in countries like India, Nepal, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh. They also grow in other parts of Asia, including Southeast Asia.
Growing_Requirements: Peepal trees are hardy and can grow in a variety of soil types. They prefer a warm climate and are often found in open spaces, including near temples, villages, and urban areas.
Uses_and_Benefits: The Peepal Tree has cultural and religious significance, particularly in Hinduism and Buddhism. It is believed to be the tree under which Gautama Buddha attained enlightenment. In traditional medicine, different parts of the tree are used for various purposes.
Conservation_Status: Ficus Religiosa is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Hibiscus Rosa-sinensis, commonly known as Hibiscus or China Rose, is a flowering shrub or small tree belonging to the Malvaceae family. It is native to East Asia and is widely cultivated for its vibrant and showy flowers.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Hibiscus Rosa-sinensis is found in various tropical and subtropical regions, including China, India, and Southeast Asia. It grows in diverse habitats, including gardens, landscapes, and natural areas.
Growing_Requirements: Hibiscus plants prefer well-drained soil and a warm climate. They require ample sunlight and can tolerate a range of temperatures.
Uses_and_Benefits: The flowers of Hibiscus Rosa-sinensis are ornamental and used in landscaping and decorative purposes. They are also used to make herbal teas, infusions, and traditional remedies with potential health benefits.
Conservation_Status: Hibiscus Rosa-sinensis is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Jasminum is a genus of flowering shrubs and vines in the Oleaceae family. Various species of Jasmine are known for their fragrant and delicate flowers. They are widely cultivated for their ornamental and aromatic qualities.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Jasmine species can be found in different regions around the world, including Asia, Africa, and Europe. They grow in diverse habitats, ranging from forests and woodlands to gardens and cultivated areas.
Growing_Requirements: The specific growing requirements for Jasmine can vary depending on the species. Generally, they prefer well-drained soil, ample sunlight, and a warm climate.
Uses_and_Benefits: Jasmine flowers are highly valued for their fragrance and are used in perfumes, cosmetics, and aromatherapy products. They are also used to make tea and infusions with potential health benefits.
Conservation_Status: The conservation status of Jasminum species can vary depending on the specific species and their geographic distribution. Some species may be endangered or threatened in certain regions.

Description: Mangifera Indica, commonly known as Mango, is a fruit-bearing tree belonging to the Anacardiaceae family. It is native to South Asia and is widely cultivated for its delicious and juicy fruits.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Mango trees are cultivated in various tropical and subtropical regions around the world, including countries like India, Thailand, Mexico, and Brazil. They thrive in warm climates and require a dry period to initiate flowering.
Growing_Requirements: Mango trees prefer well-drained soil and ample sunlight. They require a hot and dry climate for fruit production. Different varieties of mangoes have specific growing requirements.
Uses_and_Benefits: Mango fruits are highly prized for their sweet and tangy flavor. They are consumed fresh and used in a wide range of culinary preparations, including desserts, beverages, and savory dishes. Mangoes are also a rich source of vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants.
Conservation_Status: Mangifera Indica is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Mentha is a genus of aromatic herbaceous plants in the Lamiaceae family. It includes various species of mint, known for their characteristic fragrance and culinary uses.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Different species of mint can be found in various regions around the world. They often grow in moist and temperate climates, such as North America, Europe, and Asia.
Growing_Requirements: Mint plants thrive in moist soil and partial shade. They can be grown in containers or in garden beds. Mint species may have slightly different growing preferences.
Uses_and_Benefits: Mint leaves are widely used in culinary applications, such as flavoring teas, beverages, salads, and desserts. They also have medicinal properties and are used in traditional remedies for digestive issues and respiratory ailments.
Conservation_Status: The conservation status of specific mint species may vary. Some rare or endemic species of mint may be threatened in certain regions.

Description: Moringa Oleifera, commonly known as Drumstick tree or Horseradish tree, is a fast-growing deciduous tree belonging to the Moringaceae family. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and is known for its nutritious leaves, flowers, and pods.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Drumstick trees are found in various parts of South Asia, including India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. They also grow in other tropical and subtropical regions around the world.
Growing_Requirements: Moringa trees can adapt to a range of soil types, but they prefer well-drained soil. They thrive in warm climates and can tolerate drought conditions.
Uses_and_Benefits: Moringa leaves, flowers, and pods are highly nutritious and are consumed as a vegetable. They are rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. Moringa is also used in traditional medicine and as a natural supplement.
Conservation_Status: Moringa Oleifera is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Muntingia Calabura, commonly known as Jamaica Cherry or Gasagase, is a small, fast-growing tree belonging to the Muntingiaceae family. It is native to tropical regions of the Americas and is known for its cherry-like fruits.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Jamaica Cherry trees can be found in various countries, including parts of the Caribbean, Central America, and South America. They grow in a range of habitats, including forests, open fields, and disturbed areas.
Growing_Requirements: Jamaica Cherry trees prefer well-drained soil and full sun. They are adaptable to different soil types and can tolerate drought conditions.
Uses_and_Benefits: The fruits of Muntingia Calabura are edible and have a sweet-tart flavor. They are often eaten fresh or used in jams, jellies, and beverages. The tree also has some medicinal uses in traditional practices.
Conservation_Status: Muntingia Calabura is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Murray Koenigii, commonly known as Curry tree or Curry leaf, is a small, evergreen tree belonging to the Rutaceae family. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and is known for its aromatic leaves, which are used as a culinary spice.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Curry trees are native to India, Sri Lanka, and other parts of South Asia. They are also cultivated in other tropical and subtropical regions around the world. They thrive in warm climates.
Growing_Requirements: Curry trees prefer well-drained soil and a sunny location. They can tolerate a range of temperatures but require protection from frost. The tree can be grown in containers or planted in the ground.
Uses_and_Benefits: The leaves of Murray Koenigii are highly valued for their distinct flavor and aroma, which is used in various curry dishes and culinary preparations. They are also believed to have medicinal properties in traditional medicine.
Conservation_Status: Murray Koenigii is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Nerium Oleander is a flowering shrub belonging to the Apocynaceae family. It is native to the Mediterranean region and is cultivated for its showy and fragrant flowers. However, it is important to note that Oleander is toxic and should be handled with care.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Oleander is cultivated in many parts of the world, including regions with a Mediterranean climate. It is often seen in gardens, parks, and landscapes.
Growing_Requirements: Oleander prefers well-drained soil and full sun. It can tolerate a range of soil types and is drought-tolerant once established. However, it is important to note that all parts of the plant are toxic and should be handled with caution.
Uses_and_Benefits: Despite its toxic nature, Oleander is appreciated for its attractive flowers, which come in various colors. It is used as an ornamental plant in landscaping, but caution should be exercised to prevent ingestion or contact with the toxic compounds.
Conservation_Status: Nerium Oleander is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Nyctanthes Arbor-tristis, commonly known as Parijata or Night-flowering Jasmine, is a small, deciduous tree belonging to the Oleaceae family. It is native to South Asia and is known for its fragrant, star-shaped white flowers.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Parijata trees are native to the Indian subcontinent, including countries like India, Nepal, and Bangladesh. They are often found in gardens, temple premises, and cultural landscapes.
Growing_Requirements: Parijata trees prefer well-drained soil and a warm climate. They require ample sunlight for flowering. The tree can be grown in containers or planted in the ground.
Uses_and_Benefits: The flowers of Nyctanthes Arbor-tristis are highly fragrant and are used in religious rituals, garlands, and traditional decorations. They are also associated with cultural and mythological significance in certain communities.
Conservation_Status: Nyctanthes Arbor-tristis is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Ocimum Tenuiflorum, commonly known as Tulsi or Holy Basil, is a perennial herb belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and is revered for its medicinal and cultural significance.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Tulsi is cultivated and found in various parts of South Asia, including India, Sri Lanka, and Nepal. It is often grown in gardens, temple premises, and household settings.
Growing_Requirements: Tulsi plants prefer well-drained soil and a warm climate. They require ample sunlight and can be grown in pots or directly in the ground.
Uses_and_Benefits: Tulsi is considered a sacred plant in Hinduism and is used in religious ceremonies and rituals. It has medicinal properties and is used in traditional Ayurvedic medicine for various health ailments. The leaves are also used in culinary preparations and herbal teas.
Conservation_Status: Ocimum Tenuiflorum is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Piper Betle, commonly known as Betel leaf, is a climbing vine belonging to the Piperaceae family. It is native to South and Southeast Asia and is widely cultivated for its leaves, which are used in traditional practices and as a mild stimulant.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Betel plants are found in various countries across South and Southeast Asia, including India, Bangladesh, Indonesia, and Thailand. They grow in warm and humid climates.
Growing_Requirements: Betel plants prefer well-drained soil and partial shade. They require a warm and humid environment for optimal growth. The plant can be grown on trellises or as ground cover.
Uses_and_Benefits: Betel leaves are used in traditional practices, such as chewing betel quid, which often includes other ingredients like areca nut, slaked lime, and tobacco. Betel leaves are also used for medicinal purposes and have cultural significance in certain communities.
Conservation_Status: Betle is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Plectranthus Amboinicus, commonly known as Mexican Mint or Indian Borage, is a perennial herb belonging to the Lamiaceae family. It is native to Southern and Eastern Africa but is widely cultivated in various tropical regions for its culinary and medicinal uses.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Mexican Mint plants are cultivated in many parts of the world, including India, Indonesia, and certain regions of the Americas. They are often grown in gardens and as potted plants.
Growing_Requirements: Mexican Mint prefers well-drained soil and partial shade. It can tolerate a range of temperatures but thrives in warm climates. The plant is often grown in containers or as a garden herb.
Uses_and_Benefits: The leaves of Plectranthus Amboinicus have a distinct aroma and are used as a culinary herb in various cuisines. They are also known for their medicinal properties and are used in traditional remedies for respiratory ailments and digestive issues.
Conservation_Status: Plectranthus Amboinicus is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Pongamia Pinnata, commonly known as Indian Beech or Karanj, is a medium-sized tree belonging to the Fabaceae family. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and is known for its timber, oilseeds, and potential for biofuel production.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Indian Beech trees are found in various parts of South Asia, including India, Bangladesh, and Sri Lanka. They also grow in other tropical and subtropical regions around the world. They are often found along rivers, in coastal areas, and in disturbed habitats.
Growing_Requirements: Pongamia Pinnata prefers well-drained soil and full sun. It is a hardy tree that can tolerate drought conditions and a variety of soil types.
Uses_and_Benefits: Pongamia Pinnata has multiple uses. The seeds of the tree contain oil that can be used for various purposes, including biodiesel production and traditional medicine. The timber is used in construction and as fuelwood.
Conservation_Status: Pongamia Pinnata is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Psidium Guajava, commonly known as Guava, is a small to medium-sized tree belonging to the Myrtaceae family. It is native to Central America and is now cultivated in tropical and subtropical regions worldwide for its delicious and nutritious fruits.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Guava trees are cultivated in many countries with suitable climates, including India, Brazil, Mexico, and Thailand. They are often found in gardens, orchards, and home landscapes.
Growing_Requirements: Guava trees prefer well-drained soil and full sun. They are adaptable to different soil types and can tolerate drought conditions. Pruning is often required to maintain their shape and improve fruit production.
Uses_and_Benefits: Guava fruits are highly nutritious, rich in vitamins, minerals, and antioxidants. They are consumed fresh and used in various culinary preparations, such as juices, jams, and desserts. Guava leaves are also used in traditional medicine.
Conservation_Status: Psidium Guajava is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Punica Granatum, commonly known as Pomegranate, is a small deciduous tree belonging to the Lythraceae family. It is native to the Middle East and has been cultivated for thousands of years for its distinctive fruits and ornamental value.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Pomegranate trees are cultivated in various countries with suitable climates, including India, Iran, Spain, and the United States. They are often found in gardens, orchards, and cultural landscapes.
Growing_Requirements: Pomegranate trees prefer well-drained soil and full sun. They can tolerate a range of soil types but require regular watering during the growing season. Pruning is often done to maintain the tree's shape and improve fruit production.
Uses_and_Benefits: Pomegranate fruits are known for their sweet-tart flavor and numerous health benefits. They are consumed fresh, juiced, and used in culinary preparations. Pomegranate juice and extracts are also popular for their antioxidant properties.
Conservation_Status: Punica Granatum is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Santalum Album, commonly known as Sandalwood, is a medium-sized evergreen tree belonging to the Santalaceae family. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and Southeast Asia and is known for its highly fragrant wood, which is used in various industries.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Sandalwood trees are native to India, Indonesia, and other countries in the region. They are often found in dry forests, savannas, and plantations.
Growing_Requirements: Sandalwood trees prefer well-drained soil and a warm, tropical climate. They require partial shade when young but can tolerate full sun as they mature. The tree is slow-growing and requires several years to develop the highly valued heartwood.
Uses_and_Benefits: The heartwood of Santalum Album is highly prized for its fragrance and is used in the production of incense, perfumes, and various wood-based products. Sandalwood oil is also extracted for its aromatic properties and is used in traditional medicine.
Conservation_Status: Santalum Album is considered a threatened species due to overexploitation and habitat loss in its native range.

Description: Syzygium Cumini, commonly known as Jamun or Indian Blackberry, is a medium-sized evergreen tree belonging to the Myrtaceae family. It is native to the Indian subcontinent and is known for its edible fruits and medicinal properties.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Jamun trees are found in various parts of South Asia, including India, Sri Lanka, and Bangladesh. They are often cultivated in gardens, orchards, and urban landscapes.
Growing_Requirements: Jamun trees prefer well-drained soil and full sun. They can tolerate a range of soil types but require regular watering during the growing season. Pruning is often done to maintain tree shape and improve fruit production.
Uses_and_Benefits: Jamun fruits are rich in nutrients and have a unique sweet-tart flavor. They are consumed fresh and used in various culinary preparations, such as desserts, beverages, and jams. The tree also has medicinal uses in traditional practices.
Conservation_Status: Syzygium Cumini is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Syzygium Jambos, commonly known as Rose Apple or Jambos, is a medium-sized evergreen tree belonging to the Myrtaceae family. It is native to Southeast Asia and is cultivated for its fragrant flowers and edible fruits.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Rose Apple trees are cultivated in various tropical and subtropical regions worldwide. They are often found in gardens, parks, and urban landscapes.
Growing_Requirements: Rose Apple trees prefer well-drained soil and full sun. They can tolerate a range of soil types but require regular watering during the growing season. Pruning is often done to maintain tree shape and improve fruit production.
Uses_and_Benefits: The fruits of Syzygium Jambos have a crisp texture and a floral aroma. They are consumed fresh and used in various culinary preparations, such as salads, desserts, and preserves. The tree's flowers are also prized for their fragrance.
Conservation_Status: Syzygium Jambos is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Tabernaemontana Divaricata, commonly known as Crape Jasmine or Pinwheel Flower, is a small evergreen shrub belonging to the Apocynaceae family. It is native to Southeast Asia and is cultivated for its attractive flowers and ornamental value.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Crape Jasmine is cultivated in various tropical and subtropical regions worldwide. It is often found in gardens, landscapes, and as a potted plant.
Growing_Requirements: Crape Jasmine prefers well-drained soil and partial shade. It requires a warm climate and protection from frost. The plant can be grown in containers or planted in the ground.
Uses_and_Benefits: The flowers of Tabernaemontana Divaricata are star-shaped and come in various colors, including white, pink, and yellow. They are used as ornamental flowers in gardens and floral arrangements.
Conservation_Status: Tabernaemontana Divaricata is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.

Description: Trigonella Foenum-graecum, commonly known as Fenugreek, is an annual herb belonging to the Fabaceae family. It is native to the Mediterranean region and is cultivated for its culinary and medicinal uses.
Distribution_and_Habitat: Fenugreek is cultivated in various countries with suitable climates, including India, Egypt, and Morocco. It is often found in kitchen gardens and as a spice crop.
Growing_Requirements: Fenugreek plants prefer well-drained soil and full sun. They can be grown in pots or directly in the ground. The leaves and seeds of the plant are harvested for culinary purposes.
Uses_and_Benefits: Fenugreek leaves and seeds are used as a spice in many cuisines, especially in Indian and Middle Eastern dishes. They have a distinct aroma and flavor. Fenugreek also has medicinal uses and is believed to have various health benefits.
Conservation_Status: Trigonella Foenum-graecum is not typically considered a threatened or endangered species.
